questions.question: Which HTML5 element should be used to mark up an article's main content area?
questions.explanation: The <main> element represents the main content of the document. It should be unique to the document and should not include content that is repeated across documents like sidebars, navigation links, etc.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the srcset attribute in the tag?
options: To specify multiple source files for video elements
To provide alternative text for images
To specify multiple image files for different screen sizes and resolutions
To set the source directory for images
questions.correctAnswer: To specify multiple image files for different screen sizes and resolutions
questions.explanation: The srcset attribute allows you to specify multiple image sources with different sizes/resolutions, letting browsers choose the most appropriate image based on the device's characteristics.

questions.question: Which HTML5 input type automatically validates that its value is a valid email address?
questions.explanation: HTML5 introduced the email input type which provides automatic validation of email addresses on form submission, along with appropriate keyboard layouts on mobile devices.

questions.question: What is the purpose of the <picture> element in HTML5?
options: It provides a container for multiple image sources and lets browsers choose the most suitable one
It's used for creating image galleries
It's used for adding captions to images
questions.correctAnswer: It provides a container for multiple image sources and lets browsers choose the most suitable one
questions.explanation: The element contains multiple elements and one element to provide different versions of an image for different display/device scenarios.

questions.question: Which HTML5 element is used to draw graphics via JavaScript?
questions.explanation: The <canvas> element is used to draw graphics on the fly via JavaScript. It can be used for animations, game graphics, data visualization, photo manipulation, and real-time video processing.
